ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned how to think about the sounds of the languages of the world and became extremely familiar with using the IPA symbols and diacritics to describe sounds. Theories of speech, sound change, sociophonetics, some basic anatomy and little bit of practice producing sounds.

This course was a thorough introduction to phonetics. I learned how to describe, produce, and interpret the sounds of the world's languages, and I learned  the basics of speech production and acoustics. I learned how to use software to manipulate spectrograms and waveforms to better understand sounds. I also learned a lot about experimental methods in linguistics.

I learned a lot about speech and speech production. I learned how intonation, tone, pitch, etc. works and even learned how to use the software praat. I learned the IPA and the anatomy of different parts of the body that are included in speech and speech perception.

Confidence reading and interpreting spectrograms (if you're a linguist who wants this skill, take this class). Knowledge of how to understand and talk about various domains of phonetics, including acoustic phonetics, production mechanisms of consonants and vowels, other topics like sociophonetics, sound change, continuous speech, etc.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I wouldn't make any changes to the design of the class! Learned an exceptional amount without it being unnecessarily difficult.

This is a truly excellent course. Professor Shaw is a brilliant instructor, and his enthusiasm for phonetics is totally infectious. The lectures and discussions are highly engaging, and the course is well-designed to foster understanding of the material. I can't think of any weaknesses. Please keep doing what you're doing!

Great teacher, great material. Lots of homework in the beginning of the course, much more manageable course load towards the end. The course got better and better! Interesting material covered, lots of examples. I really liked how the homework contributed to the final project in the second half of the semester.

This class is super great as is. Sections could be a bit more structured. Loved how the class was at its core a lecture but highly engaging, and the professor always took time to thoughtfully answer students' questions and curiosities.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! This was my first class in the linguistics department at Yale and it was everything I hoped for and more. Jason Shaw is a great lecturer and the readings are not too long and easy to comprehend. The final project, a phonetic analysis of a foreign language with the help of a natively-speaking informant, was a great way to solidify and explore the topics we learned in the course. Listening and production quizzes get quite a bit harder once the class has covered sounds not in the English language, but it is so rewarding to be able to recognizes sounds from other languages around the world. If you think that studying the sounds of foreign languages would be interesting to you, you will love this class. In the undergrad version of this class you'll have section once a week and Prof. Shaw has some cool interactive demos.

I would absolutely recommend the course to other students. If you are interested in linguistics at all, this course could be a great introduction, even if you've never taken a linguistics course before. If you are a more experienced linguistics student, you will get a lot out of learning about experimental methods and the acoustics of sounds! I especially recommend the course if you're a phonology student; the courses would go really well together.

Yes! I really liked the class because the teacher was very approachable and the material was hard to understand at times but we learned a lot throughout the class. If you put in the work, you'll get a lot out of this class.

Yes! There were a lot of non-linguistics majors in the class and it seemed to be accessible, although I can't speak for them. As a Linguistics major, I highly recommend this class for everyone on the Phonetics/Phonology side or if this stuff inspires you. It meets all expectations for a solid foundation in phonetics and is definitely a core class. Super solid course with no tricks, Jason is a great professor.
